stem: The maternal-fetal medicine nurse is reviewing test results for two pregnant clients. Based on the documentation in the Glucose Tolerance & Screen tab, match the finding with the correct diagnostic status.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 26-week G1P0. Presents for her routine 1-hour glucose challenge test (GCT). She was not required to fast. 
Patient B: 28-week G2P1. Had an abnormal 1-hour screen (155 mg/dL) last week. Today she is here for the definitive 3-hour oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).

rationale.correct: A 1-hour screen (GCT) < 130-140 is normal (r3). If it is above that threshold (r1), the screen is 'positive' (c2) and the patient must return for the diagnostic 3-hour test. A diagnosis of GDM (c3) is made only when TWO or more values on the 3-hour test (OGTT) are elevated (r2).
clinicalPearls: The 1-hour GCT is a screen (No fasting needed).
The 3-hour OGTT is diagnostic (Fasting MUST occur).
Screening usually occurs between 24-28 weeks of gestation.

questionTrap.trap: Diagnosing GDM based solely on a high 1-hour screen.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that a SCREEN only finds people who *might* have it. You need the 3-hour test to confirm it.

mnemonic.title: One is None, Two is True
mnemonic.expansion: 1 high on 3-hour = keep testing. 2 high on 3-hour = True GDM.
